TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Coarse-loamy, mixed, superactive Typic Haplocryalfs

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Ashcroft sandy loam, forested.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
01--3 to 2 inches; undecomposed twigs, bark, and needles.
02--2 to 0 inches; partially decomposed organic material.
A2--0 to 6 inches; pinkish gray (5YR 6/2) sandy loam, dark reddish gray (5YR 4/2) moist; moderate fine granular structure; weak platy structure in some places; soft, very friable; medium acid; clear smooth boundary.  (4 to 10 inches thick)
B21t--6 to 12 inches; reddish brown (2.5YR 5/3) gravelly sandy loam, reddish brown (2.5YR 4/3) moist; weak medium subangular blocky structure that parts to moderate fine granules; slightly hard, very friable; thin discontinuous clay films on horizontal and vertical faces of peds, clay bridges between sand grains, and clay coatings on sand grains; approximately 15 percent pebbles and cobbles; the peds in the upper part of this horizon may have gray coatings; slightly acid; clear smooth boundary.  (4 to 12 inches thick)
B22t--12 to 26 inches; reddish brown (2.5YR 5/3) gravelly sandy loam, reddish brown (2.5YR 4/3) moist; moderate medium subangular blocky structure that parts to moderate fine subangular blocks; slightly hard, very friable; thin discontinuous clay films on peds; clay bridges between sand grains, and clay coatings on sand grains; 25 percent pebbles and cobbles; slightly acid; gradual smooth boundary.  (12 to 18 inches thick)
B3--26 to 32 inches; reddish brown (2.5YR 5/3) gravelly loamy sand, reddish brown (2.5YR 4/3) moist; single grained; soft, very friable; few thin discontinuous clay films on some peds and clay coatings on some sand grains; 20 percent pebbles and cobbles; neutral; gradual smooth boundary.  (4 to 10 inches thick)
C--32 to 48 inches; weak red (10R 5/3) gravelly sand, weak red (10R 4/3) moist; single grained; loose; 20 percent pebbles and cobbles; slightly acid; gradual smooth boundary.  (10 to several feet thick)
R--48 to 52 inches; hard conglomerate.

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Gunnison County, Colorado; adjacent to Italian Creek Trail in Sec. 28, T. 13 S., R. 84 W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  Thickness of the solum ranges from 20 to 50 or more inches.  Depth to bedrock ranges from 40 inches to 10 or 12 feet; however, most areas of this soil have bedrock at depths of 4 to 5 feet.  Noncontrasting coarse textured material occurs at depths of 20 to 40 inches.  Rock fragments in the solum and C horizon range from 0 to 35 percent by volume and are mainly of gravel and cobble size.  Reaction ranges from pH 5.5 through 7.0.
The A2 horizon has hue of 5YR through 2.5YR, value of 6 to 7 dry, 4 or 5 moist, and chroma of 2 through 4.  Structure is typically weak platy or granular but is weak subangular blocky in some pedons.  Dry consistence is soft or slightly hard.
The B2t horizon has hue of 5YR through 10R, value of 5 or 6 dry, 4 or 5 moist, and chroma of 3 through 5.  This horizon had medium to coarse, moderate to strong subangular blocky structure.  Dry consistence is slightly hard or hard.  It is sandy loam and ranges in clay from 7 to 18 percent.
The C horizon has hue of 5YR through 10R.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  This is the Lake Creek series.  Lake Creek soils have more than 35 percent coarse fragments in the solum and have bedrock at depths of less than 40 inches.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  The Ashcroft soils are on gently to very steeply sloping upland hills, ridges, or mountain sides, and alluvial fans associated with these land forms.  Slope gradients range from 2 to 60 or more percent.  They formed in alluvial fan materials or deep residuum weathered from reddish-colored conglomerate.  At the type location the average annual precipitation is 20 inches, with peak periods of precipitation occurring during the spring and summer.  The mean annual temperature is about 34 degrees F.  The frost-free season is less than 60 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Chubbs, Hierro, and Sawcreek soils.  Chubbs and Hierro soils have more than 18 percent clay in the control section.  Sawcreek soils have mollic epipedons.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; medium to rapid runoff; moderate permeability.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  These soils are used for rangeland, for forestry, and for recreational purposes.  Principal native vegetation is lodgepole pine, Engelmann spruce, subalpine fir, vaccinium, mosses, and lichens.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Mountainous areas of central Colorado.  The series is of small extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Bozeman, Montana

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED:  Taylor River Area, Gunnison, Colorado, 1975.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS:  Last updated by the state 6/75.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
